attributes.title: The Influence of Emotional Awareness on Neural Function during Emotion Regulation in Adolescents and Children

q1.value: The Influence of Emotional Awareness on Neural Function during Emotion Regulation in Adolescents and Children

q2.value: Eli Susman, Katie A. McLaughlin, David Weissman

q3.value:
Emotional awareness is reflected by the ability to recognize, differentiate and label emotional states (Croyle & Waltz, 2002; Lane & Schwartz, 1987; Lennartsson et al., 2017). In addition to feeling an emotion, emotion awareness requires cognitive reflection on what is being experienced (Barrett et al., 2001; Croyle & Waltz, 2002). Emotional awareness is widely accepted as a prerequisite for adaptive emotion regulation abilities (Barrett et al., 2001; Lambie & Marcel, 2002; Teasdale, 1999). Barrett et al. (2001) suggest that knowing what one is feeling can inform how to go about coping with those emotions. Indeed, individuals with higher emotional awareness are more likely to use adaptive emotion regulation strategies like cognitive reappraisal compared to maladaptive strategies like suppression (Subic-Wrana et al., 2014). 

Cognitive reappraisal is an emotion regulation technique where one reframes what they are experiencing so as to make it less distressing. The technique involves maintaining the intention to reappraise in working memory, using semantic memory to generate alternative appraisals given the context of the situation, selecting a new appraisal, and then updating and sustaining this reappraisal in working memory—all while evaluating whether or not the appraisal was successful in regulating one’s emotional state (Ochsner & Gross, 2008). Cognitive reappraisal has consistently been shown to activate the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC), the dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (dmPFC), and ventrolateral prefrontal cortex (vlPFC) and is associated with decreased amygdala activation relative to passive viewing of emotional stimuli without using reappraisal (Buhle et al., 2014; Kalisch, 2009). The amygdala is activated in response to stimuli that have motivational salience (Lee et al., 2012; Santos et al., 2011). The dlPFC is involved with manipulation of verbal and spatial knowledge, and thus may be central to continuously updating appraisals in working memory (i.e. maintaining the intention to reappraise in working memory) (Barbey et al., 2013; Buhle et al., 2014; Wager & Smith, 2003). On the other hand, the vlPFC may be involved with selection and inhibition of appraisals, and the dmPFC may support inferring higher-level meaning from stimuli and affective states (i.e. appraisal), particularly from negative emotional stimuli (Baetens et al., 2017; Buhle et al., 2014; Etkin et al., 2011). 

We expect emotional awareness will support emotion regulation in two ways. First, we anticipate higher emotion awareness will make regulation using cognitive reappraisal more effective, since low emotional awareness is associated with ineffective regulation (Kalokerinos et al., 2019). Specifically, higher emotional awareness should be associated with greater reduction in amygdala activation during reappraisal relative to passive viewing. Second, we expect that that higher emotional awareness will be associated with greater use of reappraisal, and less use of suppression and rumination (i.e., negative emotion regulation strategies).

q4.value:
1. We hypothesize that dependent variable, self-reported frequency of use of cognitive reappraisal, is positively related to independent variable, emotional awareness, after controlling for age, sex, and violence exposure.

2. We hypothesize that dependent variable amygdala activation during reappraisal (vs. reactivity) is negatively related to independent variable emotional awareness such that higher emotional awareness would be associated with lower amygdala activation during reappraisal after controlling for age, sex, and violence exposure.

3. We will conduct an exploratory whole-brain analysis of activation during reappraisal (vs. reactivity) to identify significant clusters of voxels that are related to independent variable emotional awareness, after controlling for age, sex, and violence exposure.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
2019 Child Trauma and the Development of Neural Systems Underlying Emotion Regulation (NIH R01MH103291) is a cross-sectional design.

Participants completed a neuroimaging task that measured neural activation during passive viewing and cognitive reappraisal in response to negative stimuli. They were instructed to either look at images of emotional neutral or negative faces or attempt to regulate their response using cognitive reappraisal. Participants rated the valence of their emotional response after each image was presented. Participants were instructed to relax between trials.

Emotional awareness was assessed by the “Poor Awareness” subscale of the Expression and Emotion Scale for Children (EESC). The EESC is a questionnaire that uses a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (not at all true) to 5 (extremely true). The eight-item Poor Awareness subscale measures lack of emotional awareness (e.g., “Sometimes I just don’t have words to describe how I feel”; “I have feelings I can’t figure out”). Strong reliability, validity, and internal consistency of the Poor Awareness subscale have been well-documented (Penza-Clyve & Zeman, 2002; Sim et al., 2009; Simon et al., 2017; Zeman et al., 2002). Previous studies have not found any gender differences on the poor awareness subscale (Sim et al., 2009).

Because half the sample was trauma exposed (n = 79), all analyses control for trauma exposure. More details on how participants were categorized can be found be found in Weissman et al. (2019).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Emotional awareness, self-reported cognitive reappraisal, and neural activation during cognitive reappraisal have all been examined separately in previous studies. However, the particular analyses in this study have not been conducted.

question.value:
160 participants between the ages of 8 and 17 were recruited at adoption programs, food banks, schools, after-school and prevention programs, medical clinics, shelters, parenting programs, and the general community in Seattle, WA between January 2015 and June 2017. The aim was to recruit a sample with high variability in trauma and maltreatment exposure. Thus, we targeted areas such as clinics that served a predominantly low-SES population, high-crime neighborhoods, and programs affiliated with Child Protective Services. Inclusion and exclusion criteria were assessed at the first visit.

Inclusion criteria for the maltreated group, consisted of exposure to physical or sexual abuse or direct witnessing of domestic violence (i.e., violence directed towards a caregiver). Participants in the control group were required to have neither maltreatment nor violence exposure. Participants were matched on age, gender, and handedness. Exclusion criteria included IQ < 80, pervasive developmental disorder, active psychotic symptoms, mania, substance abuse, other safety concerns, as well as any standard contraindications for MRI scanning (e.g., braces).

2019 Child Trauma and the Development of Neural Systems Underlying Emotion Regulation (NIH R01MH103291) Data consist of 151 subjects. 160 participants initially completed the emotion regulation fMRI task. However, 9 participants were excluded due to excessive motion during scanning (n=2), not responding during more than 2 runs of the fMRI Task (n=2), incompletion of the task (n=4), and significant non-maltreatment-related violence exposure (n=1).

q13.value: 2019 Child Trauma and the Development of Neural Systems Underlying Emotion Regulation (NIH R01MH103291) Data consist of 151 subjects.

q14.value: 151 participants is sufficient to detect an effect size of r=0.25 with power of 0.876.

question.value:
1. IV: Emotional Awareness
	A. EESC Poor Awareness Subscale (higher scores are equivalent of lower emotional awareness)
	B. Between participant
	C. Orthogonal to all DVs
2. DV: Self-reported frequency of use of cognitive reappraisal
	A. Between participant
	B. Covariates included age, sex, and violence exposure. Half of the participants in this study were recruited for violence exposure, which has been associated with lower emotional awareness and neural activation during cognitive reappraisal.
3. DV: Amygdala Activation during reappraisal (vs. reactivity)
	A. Between participant
	B. Covariates included age, sex, and violence exposure. 
4. DV: Exploratory Whole Brain-Analysis
	A. Between participant
	B. Covariates included age, sex, and violence exposure.

1. IV: Emotional Awareness 
	A. Questionnaire: Expression and Emotion Scale for Children (EESC)
	B. Sum Score of Poor-Awareness Component
2. DV: Self-Reported Cognitive Reappraisal Frequency
	A. Questionnaire: Emotion Regulation Questionnaire (ERQ)
	B. Mean of Cognitive Reappraisal Items
3. DV: Amygdala Activation during reappraisal (vs. reactivity)
	A. fMRI
	B. Reappraisal activation- Reactivity activation
	C. Derived from an ROI that’s an overlap from significant activation from the task overall with the Harvard/oxford subcortical atlas. For amygdala we will use a whole brain analysis in the whole group to identify regions that have greater activation during reactivity vs. reappraisal, then find significant areas that overlap with the Harvard/Oxford atlas region for the amygdala (Rodman et al., 2019). To investigate amygdala activation, we will conduct a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis, separately for the left and right amygdala. We will create functional ROIs by overlapping the map of activation during reactivity vs. reappraisal in the entire sample with a structural mask of the amygdala from the Harvard-Oxford subcortical atlas (20% threshold), as done in Rodman et al. (2019).
4.	Exploratory Whole Brain Analysis
	A. fMRI
	B. Reappraisal activation- Reactivity activation

1. Plan of analysis: Linear Regression 
	A. IVs: Emotional Awareness (EESC)
	B. Outcome Variables: Self-Reported Cognitive Reappraisal Frequency (ERQ)
	C. Control Variables: Age, Sex, and Violence Exposure
2. Plan of analysis: Linear Regression 
	A. IVs: Emotional Awareness (EESC)
	B. Outcome Variables: amygdala activation during reappraisal (vs. reactivity)
	C. Control Variables: Age, Sex, and Violence Exposure
3. Exploratory plan of analysis: Whole Brain Linear Regression using FSL FEAT (FLAME 1)
	A. IVs: Emotional Awareness (EESC)
	B. Outcome Variables: activation during reappraisal (vs. reactivity)
	C. Control Variables: Age, Sex, and Violence Exposure
	D. The voxel-wise significance threshold will be 0.005. The AFNIs 3dClustSim will be used to determine the appropriate cluster size for multiple comparison corrections, with an alpha of 0.05.

However, 9 participants were excluded due to excessive motion during scanning (n=2), not responding during more than 2 runs of the fMRI Task (n=2), incompletion of the task (n=4), and significant non-maltreatment-related violence exposure (n=1).

	A. fMRI

	C. Derived from an ROI that’s an overlap from significant activation from the task overall with the Harvard/oxford subcortical atlas. For amygdala we will use a whole brain analysis in the whole group to identify regions that have greater activation during reactivity vs. reappraisal, then find significant areas that overlap with the Harvard/Oxford atlas region for the amygdala (Rodman et al., 2019). To investigate amygdala activation, we will conduct a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis, separately for the left and right amygdala. We will create functional ROIs by overlapping the map of activation during reactivity vs. reappraisal in the entire sample with a structural mask of the amygdala from the Harvard-Oxford subcortical atlas (20% threshold), as done in Rodman et al. (2019).

attributes.title: Using virtual reality to test fears among adolescents with social anxiety disorder: A multiple case series
attributes.description: Social anxiety disorder (SAD) is characterised by a fear of negative evaluation leading to severe distress and avoidance. SAD is common and can have a significant negative impact on many aspects of life in both childhood and adulthood (e.g. on school attendance and attainment, relationships and jobs). It is often diagnosed in early adolescence, with a median age of onset of 13 years. However, when left untreated, SAD typically persists into adulthood. As such, effective, early interventions are important. SAD in young people is particularly resistant to the current psychological treatments that are used, but recent evidence suggests that an approach that is used successfully to treat SAD in adults may also be successful in treating SAD in young people. However, this treatment involves young people entering social situations to test out theories about the consequences of feared situations. This can be difficult to do within therapy sessions in practice, particularly due to limited access to relevant environments and the increased burden this causes in terms of therapist time and resources. Recently, virtual reality (VR) software has been applied as a means to conduct exposure to social situations and, for example, for conducting behavioural experiments within treatment of adults with paranoid delusions. Given its success so far, the current study seeks to conduct a preliminary investigation of the potential use of VR in the treatment of performance fears among adolescents with SAD by assessing whether young people experience performance fears and negative thoughts in VR social scenarios, whether these change after conducting a behavioural experiment to test out fears in the VR environment, and whether any new learning generalises to real world scenarios.

q1.value: Using virtual reality to test fears among adolescents with social anxiety disorder: A multiple case series

Recently, virtual reality (VR) software has been applied as a means to conduct exposure to social situations and, for example, for conducting behavioural experiments within treatment of adults with paranoid delusions. Given its success so far, the current study seeks to conduct a preliminary investigation of the potential use of VR in the treatment of performance fears among adolescents with SAD by assessing whether young people experience performance fears and negative thoughts in VR social scenarios, whether these change after conducting a behavioural experiment to test out fears in the VR environment, and whether any new learning generalises to real world scenarios.

q4.value: This study aims to assess (i) whether young people experience performance fears and associated negative cognitions in VR social scenarios; (ii) whether cognitive change occurs after conducting behavioural experiments within a VR environment, and (iii) whether any new learning generalises to real world scenarios.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The project will be conducted in a single phase and run as a case series to explore the feasibility of using virtual reality technology to facilitate behavioural experiments in the treatment of social anxiety in young people. The extent to which the VR environment elicits social performance fears and associated negative cognitions will be assessed through self-reported fear ratings and open questions about the young people’s cognitions throughout the session. Questionnaires and open questions will be used to assess whether cognitive change occurs after conducting behavioural experiments within VR. Generalisation of new learning will be assessed through social anxiety, cognitions and behaviour questionnaires at one week follow-up, as well as open questions about experiences over the past week.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Eligible participants will be identified through the AnDY Research Clinic by the clinical team based on the clinic’s usual assessment procedures and will be invited to provide their contact details to the research team to discuss taking part in the study. Consent and confirmation of eligibility will take place at the beginning of the research session. The research will be conducted within one x 1-hour visit to the research clinic. One week later participants will be asked to complete a set of follow up questionnaires (online) remotely.
Eligible participants will be aged between 12-17 years old and have a primary diagnosis of Social Anxiety Disorder with fears and associated negative cognitions in performance situations endorsed. Participants must have no other established diagnosis of autistic spectrum disorder, learning disability, suicidal intent or recurrent self-harm, or any other condition that is likely to affect their ability to fully engage with the VR technology and environment (e.g. photosensitive epilepsy, other visual difficulties, or physical difficulties that prevent them moving around the environment). Participants will take part before beginning any treatment within the research clinic, will be willing and able to provide informed consent and will not be identified by social services as currently "at risk" due to child protection concerns.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 12 young people.

q14.value: 12 participants will provide sufficient data to explore the feasibility of the VR environments in terms of their ability to elicit social anxiety and related cognitions and to conduct preliminary investigation of the scope to conduct behavioural experiments within the VR environments.

question.value:
To assess whether young people experience performance fears and associated negative cognitions in VR social scenarios, outcome measures will include (i) Subjective units of distress (SUDS) collected before entering VR and within each VR environment, and (ii) Open questions about cognitions within the VR environment.
To assess whether cognitive change occurs after conducting behavioural experiments within a VR environment, outcome measures will include (i) Social cognitions questionnaire (adapted for adolescents) – SCQ-A, collected at the beginning of the research session and one week after the research session, and (ii) Prediction belief ratings from behavioural experiment sheet, collected before and after each behavioural experiment.
To assess whether any new learning generalises to real world scenarios, outcome measures will include Social cognitions questionnaire (adapted for adolescents) – SCQ-A, Social behaviour questionnaire (adapted for adolescents) – SBQ - A, Liebowitz social anxiety scale (adapted for adolescents) – LSAS-A, all collected one week after the research session.

We will report descriptive data for individual (anonymised) cases. Exploratory analyses of change in (a) social cognitions pre-post the behavioural experiments and at one-week follow, and (b) social anxiety, social cognitions and safety behaviours from pre to one-week follow-up up, will be conducted using repeated measures ANOVA and standardised effect sizes will be reported.

q23.value: Where less than 25% of the items within a measure is missing, imputation by mean replacement will be carried out. Where more than 25% of items within a measure are missing, the full measure will be considered missing data. Participants will be included in analyses where they have full, or imputed to full, data for the outcome measures relevant to the analysis being carried out.

attributes.title: Testing for a positive eﬀect of Instagram use on oﬄine personal networks and personal well-being

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet

other.value:
Considering certain analyses such as density, participants may be removed from that analysis if they have a particularly small social network.
Any outliers will be visually screened for and data and results will be presented with and without outliers.
Participant collection will begin in the week of March 9th.
Supervisor may conduct further advanced analyses on data, post collection.

sample.value: Aim to gather a participant pool of 500 via the participant collection site called Prolific where participants will be offered +/-£5 per hour remuneration for taking part. The second study will aim to gather 200 participants.

analyses.value: Data from this study will be analysed using a combination of hierarchical regressions, looking at how Instagram use relates with emotional closeness to network members offline as well as how many social network members and how dense their social network is. And descriptive egocentric social network analyses. We would also examine the relationships between Instagram, depression, anxiety and loneliness (regressions).

dependent.value:
In this study; the social network size (number of alters) density (how many of those alters know each other) and how emotionally close those alters are to the ego will be considered in terms of both online (Instagram social network) and offline (real world social network). We will also consider Instagram use (Yang, 2016), hospital depression and anxiety scale (HADS) (Zigmong & Snaith, 1983), UCLA Loneliness scale (Russell, Peplau & Curtona, 1980).
In this study, we will be using an amended version of the GENSI tool Stark & Krosnick, (2017) to collect social network data (Stulp, 2020).

conditions.value: In this study all participants will take part in the same survey, since this research is non-experimental and correlational no variables will be controlled therefore there will be no conditions. 3 months after the first wave the participants that took part in the second wave will be put in a conditional white list  to ensure only participants who took part in the first wave take part in the  second wave.

hypothesis.value: Testing for a positive eﬀect of Instagram use on oﬄine personal networks and personal well-being. And how the social network changes after a 3 month interval.

attributes.title: Does modality of harmful action in a semi-autonomous vehicle influence responses to virtual-reality moral dilemmas?

q1.value: Does modality of harmful action in a semi-autonomous vehicle influence responses to virtual-reality moral dilemmas?

q2.value: Helen Brown, Danae Stanton-Fraser, Michael Proulx

q3.value:
In the transition towards fully autonomous cars, traffic will be a mixture of manual and semi-autonomous (SA) vehicles demanding varying degrees of human control. Therefore, minimizing traffic collisions resulting from human error remains a public-safety priority. Pre-programmed ‘morality’ algorithms dictating which human lives to save in unavoidable traffic-collisions, are not yet a reality. If collaborative decision-making between driver and vehicle is required in emergency situations, this could have severe consequences for passengers, pedestrians and other drivers. In the absence of pre-programmed morality algorithms, a pragmatic approach is to better understand human decision-making in hazardous situations in SA vehicles. 

A key factor relevant for real-life moral dilemmas that involve risk of harm to others, is our learned aversion to harmful actions. This aversion reliably generates a negative physiological response ahead of taking harmful action, which influences harm-based decision making and avoidance of harmful behaviour. On the road, our aversion to harmful actions could manifest in major decision-making events and more subtle driving-behaviours, such as taking control of automated functions in highly pedestrianized zones or excessive braking/swerving around unexpected motorcyclists. Importantly, our aversion to harmful actions is associated with the motoric and perceptual properties of harmful action learned over time. Therefore, how drivers interact physically with SA vehicles (e.g. arbitrary button presses versus learned actions such as steering, accelerating) to take or avoid actions that ‘feel’ harmful, could have implications for driving behaviours. 

This study will investigate whether physiological responses of participants predicts harm-avoidance behaviour in virtual-reality (VR) moral dilemma driving simulations and whether this differs depending on the input modality of harmful action. Participants will experience either a button-press condition (non-aversive) or accelerator pedal condition (aversive). A second aim of this study is to explore individual differences in interoception (perception of and attendance to internal bodily sensations) as a moderator between physiological responses generated by the prospect of carrying out harm and the decision to carry out harm, or not.

q4.value:
H1. Does modality of harmful action influence physiological responses and decisions to carry out harmful actions in VR moral dilemma driving simulations?

H2. Does interoception influence the relationship between physiological responses to VR moral dilemmas and harmful actions carried out?

H3.1. Does interoception predict ratings of presence in VR? 
H3.2. Does presence predict physiological responses and/or moral decision-making in VR?

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The between-subjects factor will be ‘Input Condition’: button-press OR foot-pedal. 
-	For the button-press condition, overriding a Virtual Reality vehicle’s autobrake function involves pushing a button on the middle of the steering wheel. 
-	For the foot-pedal condition, participants will need to press a mock-up of an accelerator foot-pedal. 

Dependent variables 
Participants will experience six moral dilemma scenarios. Moral decisions will be measured as the presence (or absence) of a button-press or foot-pedal press in each condition. The dependent variables will be harm-aversion and outcome-maximisation, calculated for each participant based on their choice to carry out harmful actions (or not) when harm results in saving more people and when it does not (Conway & Gawronski, 2013). Response time will also be measured (if harmful action is taken). Physiological data will be analysed as both dependent and independent variables depending on the analysis.

q9.value: Simple- equal numbers in each condition. Aim to have similar representation of males/females, and age groups in each condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
The pre-registration is being submitted following 8 participants undertaking the experiment. This was due to unavoidable delays for the collaborators to make comment on the pre-registration.
As data has only been collected for 10 % of the overall sample, I am so far naive to any patterns in the data and the hypotheses have remained unchanged since prior to creation of data. The physiological data is indecipherable without lengthy pre-processing procedures and the qualtrics questionnaire data has not been scrutinised in any way. Access to the data is currently restricted to the lead researcher.

question.value:
Healthy adults will be recruited between the age of 18 and 50 who have held a valid driver’s licence in the past 5 years.

Participants will be excluded if: they are above or below the age range of 18-50 years old; currently pregnant; have a heart/gastrointestinal condition or received surgery to these areas; currently experiencing mental health problems or mental illness; have a history of renal problems; have current physical conditions or medication that affect diet or weight or ability to safely take part in the study; have not held a valid driver’s license; been involved in any road traffic collisions or traumatic incidents in a vehicle in the past. 

For health and safety reasons when using VR technology, participant’s will be asked to disclose risk factors on the VR screening checklist. This is a deliberately exhaustive list, and so participation/risk will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. Key risk factors warranting exclusion will be emphasised on the recruitment advertisement and in any pre-study communication.

Participants will be recruited from University of Bath Student Participant Pool and from the Psychology Department community panel database. The study will be advertised internally in the University of Bath’s recruitment page and on the noticeboard in the psychology department and externally via print media (e.g. flyers, posters). The study will also be advertised on various online platforms such as: Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn and other email networks. Participants will receive £10 per hour for their time or course credit, if enrolled as undergraduate students.

q14.value: Using G*power (α = 0.95, β = 0.8), sample size recommendation is 51 participants per condition (n=102), estimating medium effect sizes (d=0.5). Considering financial costs of participant payment and length of the study, a sample size of 40 people per condition will be a more feasible target.

question.value:
The between-subjects factor will be ‘Input Condition’: button-press OR foot-pedal. 
-	For the button-press condition, overriding a VR vehicle’s autobrake function involves pushing a button on the middle of a mock-up steering wheel. 
-	For the foot-pedal condition, participants will need to press a mock-up of an accelerator foot-pedal.

Dependent variables 
Participants will experience six moral dilemma scenarios. Moral decisions will be measured as the presence (or absence) of a button-press or foot-pedal press in each condition. The dependent variables will be:
-  harm-aversion and outcome-maximisation, calculated for each participant based on their choice to carry out harmful actions (or not) when harm results in saving more people and when it does not (Conway & Gawronski, 2013).
-Physiological data will be analysed as both dependent and independent variables depending on the analysis. 
- Response time per condition (if harmful action is taken)
-  Physiological responses pre-decision in each moral dilemma: Electrodermal, electrocardiography and impedance cardiography recordings will be collected using electrodes and wireless BIOPAC amplifiers. 

Independent variables 
1) Physiological responses pre-decision in each moral dilemma will also be explored as independent variables for several analyses.  
2) Interoceptive accuracy and awareness: performance accuracy (Garfinkel & Critchley, 2003) and confidence in estimations on heartbeat counting task (Schandry, 1981).
3) Gastric sensitivity: assessed using the water-drinking task (Zeng et al, 2007)
4) Self-report interoceptive sensibility (Body Consciousness Questionnaire- subscale 'Private Body Consciousness')
5) Presence: Slater, Utoh and Steed (SUS) Presence Questionnaire 
6) Control variables: age, sex, state and trait anxiety, VR Simulator sickness, years of driving experience, and body mass index (BMI). 

See attachment for full appendix of measures.

- Threat reactivity index: will be calculated by subtracting Cardiac output from Systemic vascular resistance from each measurement internal during the moral dilemmas. This will then be z-transformed and a total threat reactivity index calculated for each of the moral dilemma types: when 'harm' maximises outcomes and when 'harm' does not maximise outcomes.

1. 

a) Paired samples t-tests will test for the effect of moral dilemma condition* on participant's physiological responses** and overall moral decision-making tendencies***

b) A linear regression model will explore whether physiological responses to moral dilemmas** predicts overall decision-making tendencies***

* Conditions: 
(1)when harm maximises outcomes- Incongruent condition
(2)when harm does not maximise outcomes- Congruent condition

**Physiological responses
Heart rate, galvanic skin-conductance level calculated as area under the curve, threat reactivity index

***Decision-making tendencies: 
(A) action aversion score (tendency to avoid harming others irrespective of the outcome) 
(B) outcome maximisation score (tendency to 'save more lives' controlling for action aversion).
(C) Response time per condition (if button-pressed)

2) 

A one-way between-subjects ANOVA will assess the effects of the independent variable 'Input Modality' (button-press vs foot-pedal) on two dependent variables: 
         
        a) physiological responses to the VR moral dilemmas  before making a moral choice for that particular scene.

         b) Participant's moral decision-making tendencies in VR i.e. action aversion score and  outcome-maximisation score 

3) 

A hierarchical multiple regression analysis will assess the influence of any of the independent variables on both physiological responses to the moral dilemmas and participant's moral decision-making tendencies. Sex and Age will be inputted at level 1 as known predictors of moral decision-making in this field, to explore the additional influence of any other independent variables on physiology/moral decisions.

4) 

Interoception ( measures include: interoceptive accuracy on a heartbeat detection task; interoceptive meta-cognitive awareness on a heartbeat detection task;  gastric sensitivity on a water-drinking task; and interoceptive sensibility as assessed by self-report) will be explored as a moderator in the relationship between physiological responses to virtual reality moral dilemmas, and the moral decision-making tendencies of participants (action aversion versus outcome-maximisation).

 5) 

A regression analysis will examine whether interoception (all measures) predicts feelings of presence in the VR environment. 
      - If the null hypothesis is rejected, using Hayes (2013) PROCESS macro we will explore whether any influence of interoception on physiological responses and/or moral decision-making tendencies is moderated or mediated by presence experienced in VR 
           i.e. whether greater interoceptive ability influences physiological arousal or moral decisions through greater feelings of presence, or if this relationship differs as a function of higher vs lower presence ratings. 

6) 

A further regression will examine whether moral decisions made on the first trial of each condition (i.e. to harm or not to harm) predicts decisions on later trials of that condition.

q20.value:
Physiological data will be standardised (z scores) within participants to account for inter individual differences before conducting any between-subjects statistical tests. Electrodermal data will be log transformed as a normalisation procedure, as this type of data is typically skewed. Moral dilemma data i.e. participant's 'action aversion' and 'outcome maximisation'' scores may also be z-transformed prior to analysis.

Area under the curve will be calculated for electrodermal data to provide an overall measure of skin conductance activity as a function of time. To provide both amplitude and temporal information about the EDA signal.

q22.value: Participant's will be excluded based on the quality of physiological data included, and standard outlier/leverage and unusual values checks will be applied to the data ( e.g. Cook's Distance)  before conducting statistical tests.

q23.value: Exclude participant data where full dataset for that particular analysis is not present.

q24.value: - State and Trait anxiety will be explored as a potential mediator/moderator in the relationships between interoception, moral decision-making tendencies and physiological responses to the moral dilemmas. Hayes (2013) PROCESS models will be used for this analysis.

registration_responses.q1: Does modality of harmful action in a semi-autonomous vehicle influence responses to virtual-reality moral dilemmas?
registration_responses.q2: Helen Brown, Danae Stanton-Fraser, Michael Proulx
registration_responses.q3:
In the transition towards fully autonomous cars, traffic will be a mixture of manual and semi-autonomous (SA) vehicles demanding varying degrees of human control. Therefore, minimizing traffic collisions resulting from human error remains a public-safety priority. Pre-programmed ‘morality’ algorithms dictating which human lives to save in unavoidable traffic-collisions, are not yet a reality. If collaborative decision-making between driver and vehicle is required in emergency situations, this could have severe consequences for passengers, pedestrians and other drivers. In the absence of pre-programmed morality algorithms, a pragmatic approach is to better understand human decision-making in hazardous situations in SA vehicles. 

A key factor relevant for real-life moral dilemmas that involve risk of harm to others, is our learned aversion to harmful actions. This aversion reliably generates a negative physiological response ahead of taking harmful action, which influences harm-based decision making and avoidance of harmful behaviour. On the road, our aversion to harmful actions could manifest in major decision-making events and more subtle driving-behaviours, such as taking control of automated functions in highly pedestrianized zones or excessive braking/swerving around unexpected motorcyclists. Importantly, our aversion to harmful actions is associated with the motoric and perceptual properties of harmful action learned over time. Therefore, how drivers interact physically with SA vehicles (e.g. arbitrary button presses versus learned actions such as steering, accelerating) to take or avoid actions that ‘feel’ harmful, could have implications for driving behaviours. 

This study will investigate whether physiological responses of participants predicts harm-avoidance behaviour in virtual-reality (VR) moral dilemma driving simulations and whether this differs depending on the input modality of harmful action. Participants will experience either a button-press condition (non-aversive) or accelerator pedal condition (aversive). A second aim of this study is to explore individual differences in interoception (perception of and attendance to internal bodily sensations) as a moderator between physiological responses generated by the prospect of carrying out harm and the decision to carry out harm, or not.
registration_responses.q4:
H1. Does modality of harmful action influence physiological responses and decisions to carry out harmful actions in VR moral dilemma driving simulations?

H2. Does interoception influence the relationship between physiological responses to VR moral dilemmas and harmful actions carried out?

H3.1. Does interoception predict ratings of presence in VR? 
H3.2. Does presence predict physiological responses and/or moral decision-making in VR?
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: Simple- equal numbers in each condition. Aim to have similar representation of males/females, and age groups in each condition.

registration_responses.q11:
The pre-registration is being submitted following 8 participants undertaking the experiment. This was due to unavoidable delays for the collaborators to make comment on the pre-registration.
As data has only been collected for 10 % of the overall sample, I am so far naive to any patterns in the data and the hypotheses have remained unchanged since prior to creation of data. The physiological data is indecipherable without lengthy pre-processing procedures and the qualtrics questionnaire data has not been scrutinised in any way. Access to the data is currently restricted to the lead researcher.
registration_responses.q14: Using G*power (α = 0.95, β = 0.8), sample size recommendation is 51 participants per condition (n=102), estimating medium effect sizes (d=0.5). Considering financial costs of participant payment and length of the study, a sample size of 40 people per condition will be a more feasible target.
registration_responses.q20:
Physiological data will be standardised (z scores) within participants to account for inter individual differences before conducting any between-subjects statistical tests. Electrodermal data will be log transformed as a normalisation procedure, as this type of data is typically skewed. Moral dilemma data i.e. participant's 'action aversion' and 'outcome maximisation'' scores may also be z-transformed prior to analysis.

Area under the curve will be calculated for electrodermal data to provide an overall measure of skin conductance activity as a function of time. To provide both amplitude and temporal information about the EDA signal.
registration_responses.q22: Participant's will be excluded based on the quality of physiological data included, and standard outlier/leverage and unusual values checks will be applied to the data ( e.g. Cook's Distance)  before conducting statistical tests.
